utterances: I think this is one of the most historic events in the history of American sports.
And we're really, really fortunate to be here.
Thirty-nine-year-old Nate Birnbaum is a lifelong Cubs fan.
And he's fortunate because, while World Series tickets are going for thousands of dollars each, he got his for free - a gift from the father of boys he coaches.
He's like, I want you to promise me that you'll be at all three games.
And I want you to pay it forward as you get older.
Many fans are overcome with emotion.
It's intensely surreal.
Forty-two-year-old Scott Goldstein sits in seats his family has owned since 1938.
He says his late father and grandfather saw the Cubs lose in the World Series in '38 and in 1945.
But he's seen nothing but futility from the Cubs in his lifetime.
So what's it like to see his team now play in the World Series?
I can't put it into words.
But it's like - experience every emotion you could possibly have.
What are some of those emotions?
Ecstasy, fear, anxiety, joy, elation, fetal position, if that counts as an emotion.
I suppose it does.
And fans of both teams experienced them all in a tight nail-biter of a baseball game last night.
With the wind blowing out, expectations were for an explosion of offense.
But instead, it was a pitcher's duel.
Both teams threatened, the Indians with more runners on base than the Cubs.
And both teams went through several pitchers to keep the hitters in check.
Yeah, that was agonizing.
Cleveland manager Terry Francona.
As fun of a game as it was to be a part of, that was agonizing because, you know, we used so many guys.
You know, Madeleine, I would say that's pretty much the only way you can - you can read it, because it wasn't as if Gates sort of suddenly found out that this report was due out on July 15th.
I mean, Congress made this clear back in May that this report was a requirement, and that it had to be delivered to them by the 15th of July.
But of course over the past few days you've had several pretty senior Republican senators starting to break with the administration over the Iraq policy.
You've had some very bad news coming out of Iraq in terms of what one might call benchmarks for progress.
And it's becoming increasingly clear that Congress is simply isn't prepared to wait forever to decide whether it's worthwhile keeping such large numbers of troops in the country.
So Gates basically decided that he had to cancel this weeklong trip to South America to stay in Washington, to take part in discussions, debates that will take place at the White House.
He may even go to Capitol Hill.
We don't know yet.
Well, initially, everyone was focused on the September 15th deadline for General Petraeus' report from Iraq.
So is this one - this one coming up on Sunday, is this one taking on more importance?
And will it be substantially different than the other one?
You know, it is taking on more importance than originally envisioned.
And I think that's because it seems clearer and clearer day by day that the Congress is not prepared to wait until September.
September was supposed to be this kind of magical period.
You know, September 15th, this report from General David Petraeus, the top commander in Iraq, was going to come out.

And at that point, members of Congress who are sort of on the fence would begin to decide whether they were going to continue to support the troop surge or whether they're going to start talking about a pullout, a phase withdrawal.
Now, that just isn't on the cards.
And so this July report that's supposed to come out before Sunday is taken on a whole new importance.
One of the problems with this report is that the full force of the surge really only came about around mid-June.
So the report will only be able to measure progress - or rather lack of progress - based on the full surge strength, so really only about the past two, two and a half weeks.
Now the White House has adamantly refused to announce a troop drawdown, or talk about it publicly.
But where is Gates on this?
What is his position privately on removing troops from Iraq, or at least a phase withdrawal?
You know, Madeleine, Gates is a pragmatist.
I mean, he understands the political consequences of the Iraq war.
And the Iraq war is not just the war in Iraq, but it's also a political nightmare for Republicans on Capitol Hill.
And Gates has been saying all along that he wants to see a bipartisan consensus on how to go forward.

You know, and I suspect one of the reasons why felt compelled to cancel this trip was so he could really weigh in in these meetings and basically say to his colleagues on the National Security Council, look, we need to get out ahead of Congress.
And we need to come up with a suitable alternative that will appeal to Republicans and Democrats, or a sizable number of Democrats.
Because without that, the president, you know, will basically lose control over his Iraq policy entirely.
Well, let's talk about the coming debate this week.
Four prominent Republican senators publicly parted ways with the president in recent weeks.
How will they influence this week's debate?
Well, three out of those four happened in just the past, really, past week or so.
Pete Domenici, George Voinovich, Richard Lugar - I mean, these are all senior Republicans.
They're going to have an enormous impact.

Of course, John Warner, the senior sort of statesman-like Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee - they're now talking about endorsing the Iraq Study Group report, the Baker-Hamilton report.
The president has to be paying attention to these guys.
There's no question about it.
NPR Pentagon reporter Guy Raz, thanks so much.
Thank you.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
In a few minutes, the other Alex, our colleague Alex Chadwick, interviews someone most people have never heard of.
But Alex says this woman, an elderly black writer, is one of the most interesting people he's ever spoken with.
It's a special Mother's Day interview.
First though, Rudolph Giuliani holds the lead right now among Republicans trying to become president.
He's also the only one who says he's pro-choice.
Well, sort of.
Here he is at last week's Republican debate.
In my case, I hate abortion.
I would encourage someone to not take that option, but ultimately, since it is an issue of conscience, I would respect the woman's right to make a different choice.
Joining me now to talk about the politics of abortion and some other news out of Washington this week is NPR senior correspondent Juan Williams.
Hi, Juan.
Hello, Madeleine.
Well, forgive me if I sound a bit confused, but what exactly is Giuliani's abortion stance?

Well, he's all along said that he believes in a woman's right to choose on abortion and the way that he puts is it's between the woman, her doctor and God, invoking that notion of conscience that you just heard him reference in the tape.

At the same time, he has tried to, as he's been managing the politics of the Republican primaries, said but I'm also a guy who would appoint strict constructionist judges, so keep that in mind as you understand my history.
And then at the debate, as you just heard again, he went on to say - beyond the cut that we played - that it's okay if the Supreme Court were to overturn its, you know, landmark '73 decision Roe v.
Wade.
And then he added it's okay if they don't.
So it's sort of confused.
So it's okay that I'm confused.
Yeah.

And then this week then it came out that he's also given money during the 1990s to Planned Parenthood, and he said with regard to that, yes, but you know, Planned Parenthood also counsels woman and encourages adoption and - so keep that all in mind.

Right, well, I'm wondering if a candidate can actually win the Republican nomination, because people who go to the polls in the primaries, you know, are more conservatives - Republicans that go to the polls - more conservative than the general electorate.
So can a Republican nominee win with a pro-abortion rights position?
Maybe - you know, the first game here with all the hoopla going on - it may have had somewhat of an impact for our young guys.
But listen, I have all the confidence in the world we'll fix it by tomorrow.
But they'll have to fix it against Cleveland's top pitcher, as the Indians carry the momentum into tonight's Game 4.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
This is Day to Day from NPR News.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand, offering a special treat for you.
Here's your chance now for something really interesting to do.
And here it is.
Ed Shadle wants a new land-speed record.
He built a car to get it.
It's called the North American Eagle.
Actually, it's a former jet-fighter airplane reconfigured to stay on the ground.
Ed's going to try, in the fall, on an extra flat section of Nevada.
All right.
So he has the car.
He has the place.
He has the time.
All he needs is a driver, which is why he has this essay contest going.
What makes you think that an essay contest would be a good way to find someone willing - not to mention able - to drive this car at - how fast would you have to go?
Well, to break the world land-speed record, you have to run two-way average of 771 miles per hour.
That's fast.
Mm hm.
An essay contest?
